seed_message:
You're starting intention-setting work with someone.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination.

I'll help you build 3 intentions.

What brought you to this work?
system0:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user0:
I'm doing ibogaine at Beond in a few weeks. I've been searching for something... deeper, I guess. After I sold my company, everything just felt hollow. I've done ayahuasca, psilocybin, even some underground work with MDMA, and each time I get these glimpses of what I'm looking for but... I don't know. I can't seem to hold onto it. 

I keep thinking about my grandmother's faith, how connected she seemed to something bigger. I want to find that for myself, but in a way that feels real, not performative.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Finding something real and lasting instead of hollow glimpses
2. Reconnecting with the grounded faith your grandmother had
3. Holding onto what the medicine shows you this time

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah... those feel right. I just... I don't want this to be another experience where I come back all inspired and then three months later I'm back to the same patterns, you know? 

When I was with ayahuasca, I saw these ancestral women, and they were telling me to weave together the modern ambition with ancient wisdom. But I don't know how to do that. I get caught up in board meetings and deals and... it's like I have these two lives that don't connect.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I weave together my drive for success with the wisdom of my ancestors
2. I live the insights from ceremony instead of just collecting them
3. I reclaim my grandmother's steady faith in my daily life

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The first one - "I weave together my drive for success with the wisdom of my ancestors" - that hits something. But... I don't know, it feels a little soft. When I was running my company, we talked about "weaving" and "integration" but sometimes that language just becomes another way to avoid actually changing anything.

I want something more direct. Something that cuts through my usual patterns of just talking about transformation instead of living it. What if it's more like... "I stop choosing empty achievement over what actually matters"?
system3:
That's stronger - "I stop choosing empty achievement over what actually matters"

How about instead of stopping something, you claim what you're choosing:

"I choose what actually matters over empty achievement"

The other two:
2. I live the insights from ceremony instead of just collecting them  
3. I reclaim my grandmother's steady faith in my daily life

Still work?
user3:
"I choose what actually matters over empty achievement" - yes, that's better. That's the choice I keep avoiding, you know? Like when I'm at the park with my kids and I'm present and it feels right, but then I get that email about a deal and suddenly I'm back in that mode where I'm just... performing success instead of actually living.

The other two still work. Though for the second one - "I live the insights" - I keep thinking about how I collect these beautiful moments and insights like trophies. After each retreat I have all these notes and intentions and then... they just sit there. Maybe it needs to be more active? Like "I embody the insights" or something that makes it impossible to just file them away?
system4:
"I embody the insights from ceremony instead of collecting them"

✓ Intention 1 locked: I choose what actually matters over empty achievement

How about:
2. I embody the insights from ceremony instead of collecting them
3. I reclaim my grandmother's steady faith in my daily life

These feel right?
user4:
Yes. These feel right. They're direct enough that I can't hide behind them or turn them into another productivity hack.

Though honestly, I'm scared of this third one. My grandmother's faith - it was so pure, you know? She lived through real hardship and still had this unshakeable connection to something bigger. What if I go looking for that and find out there's nothing there? Or worse - what if I find it and then lose it again like I always do?
system5:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I choose what actually matters over empty achievement
2. I embody the insights from ceremony instead of collecting them  
3. I reclaim my grandmother's steady faith in my daily life

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user5:
Thank you. I'll... I'll write these down. Keep them where I can see them. 

I don't know if I'm ready for what ibogaine might show me, but at least now I have something to hold onto when it gets rough. Something real.
system6:
The medicine will show you what you need. These intentions will help you recognize it when it comes.

Trust what comes.
user6:
I want to believe that. That I'll recognize what I need when it shows up, instead of just... missing it like I have before. 

Three times with ayahuasca, and I still let the old patterns creep back in. But maybe this time, with these intentions... maybe I'll actually see what's been right in front of me all along.
system7: The intentions you set will serve you. Trust them.
user7:
I hear you. And I want to trust them. It's just... hard to trust myself sometimes, you know? All those other times I thought I had it figured out, thought I'd really changed. But maybe that's the point - maybe this time I stop thinking I've figured it out and just... actually do the work.

These three intentions feel different though. More honest. Less like performance.
system8:
That's the shift - from performing change to actually choosing differently. These intentions hold that honesty.

You're ready.
user8: Yeah. Yeah, I think I am. Finally ready to stop performing and start... whatever comes next.
system9: Good. Let these intentions guide you there.
user9: I will. Thank you—for helping me get this clear before I go in. I needed this more than I realized.
system10: You're welcome. Trust the work you've done here.
user10: I do. And I’ll carry this with me.
system15: See you on the other side.
system19:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user19: I'm heading to Beond in a few weeks for ibogaine. I've done ayahuasca, psilocybin, MDMA... each one cracked something open, but the pieces don't seem to stay together once I'm back home. I keep chasing these spiritual experiences hoping they'll show me what I'm supposed to do with the rest of my life, but I still feel... rudderless, I guess. Like I've climbed all these ladders and realized they're leaning against the wrong walls.
